articles.title: MARCH 1986
articles.summary: This document outlines a busy schedule of astronomical events and club activities planned for March and early April 1986. Highlights include several field expeditions for observing, a Messier Marathon, a board meeting combined with auction planning, and indoor star parties featuring an introductory astronomy class. The general meeting on March 22nd will host Norm Sperling presenting "The Zaniest Astro Quiz," with a significant April 5th expedition planned to Fremont Peak State Park to observe Halley's Comet.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association) has been forced to relocate its "close in" astronomical observation site from Grant Ranch County Park to C.T. English School due to new county park liability insurance requirements. C.T. English School, located in the Santa Cruz mountains, offers a good southern horizon view. Additionally, the article announces an upcoming astronomical auction, encouraging members to sell unused astronomy equipment.

articles.title: ZEIDERS ON ASTRONOMY
articles.summary: Jack Zeiders' Introductory Astronomy class on February 15th was a success, attracting over 30 attendees. The class features an interactive 'you tell me' format where students answer questions. The next session is scheduled for March 25th.

articles.title: REMINDER TO MEMBERS AND EPHEMERIS CONTRIBUTORS
articles.summary: The article reminds members and Ephemeris contributors that there will be no individual May issue. Instead, a combined April/May issue, covering calendar events into the first week of June, is planned to be mailed on March 26th.

articles.title: FEBRUARY FREEZE PARTY AT FREMONT PEAK
articles.summary: On February 15th, a 'Freeze Party' at Fremont Peak saw a small group of astronomers brave extremely cold temperatures (low 20s) but were rewarded with unusually transparent skies. Attendees attempted astrophotography and comet viewing, though Halley's Comet was not visible, while most of the SJAA club was at a separate expedition.

articles.title: PUBLIC VIEWING OF HALLEY'S COMET FROM SAN JOSE BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz is organizing a public viewing of Halley's Comet in San Jose during May and is seeking volunteers to help. The viewing sessions will take place at Branham Lane Park on multiple Friday and Saturday nights throughout the month, with observing times from 9:30 PM to 11:00 PM. Interested individuals are encouraged to contact Don Machholz to sign up and participate in a final organizational meeting in late April.

articles.title: THE 1986 MESSIER MARATHON BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article announces the 1986 Messier Marathon, an annual event scheduled for the night of March 7-8, where participants aim to observe most of the 110 Messier objects. It provides details on the observing location (C. T. English School), timing, and other celestial targets visible that night, including Comet Hartley-Good, Saturn, Mars, and Comet Halley. The author, Don Machholz, also offers contact information for observing order sheets.

articles.title: WILL BE:
articles.summary: An astronomical equipment swap meet/sale is announced for Saturday, April 26th, at 6:00 PM at the Los Gatos Red Cross. Attendees can buy and sell a wide range of astronomy-related items, with doors opening at 2:00 PM for setup and early access. The event aims to provide everything needed for an enjoyable astronomy hobby, encouraging participation from both buyers and sellers.

articles.title: PLEASE PRE-REGISTER ALL ITEMS
articles.summary: This document announces the 6th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, urging participants to pre-register items they wish to sell. It provides detailed instructions on filling out the pre-registration form, including listing items, setting minimum prices, indicating the percentage for the SJAA, and mailing the form with a SASE to Jim van Nuland to receive bidder/seller and item numbers. Pre-registration ensures smooth operation, faster processing, and priority on auction day, while proceeds support public astronomy education.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS TO THE AUCTION:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to an auction event held at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, including specific driving instructions from Hwy 17. It outlines key event details such as door opening times for bidder registration, the auction start, accepted payment methods (cash/check), a $1 bidder/seller registration fee, and refreshment availability. A partial form for bidder and item registration is also included.

articles.title: BY: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: This article offers advice to beginning amateur astronomers on selecting a telescope, emphasizing the importance of gaining experience at star parties before making a purchase. The author initially champions large Dobson-mounted Newtonians for visual deep-sky observation due to their excellent light-gathering power per dollar. However, the article also thoroughly discusses various qualifications, including specific observation types (e.g., photography, planetary), portability, budget limitations, and the concept of a versatile, compact 'second telescope' as a first purchase, ultimately advising personal preference and practical considerations.

articles.title: OBSCURE WINTER PLANETARY NEBULAE--PART I BY: STEUE GOTTLIEB AND JACK MARLING
articles.summary: This article, 'Obscure Winter Planetary Nebulaeâ€”Part I', guides deep-sky observers to less-known planetary nebulae in the winter sky, distinct from the more familiar showpieces. These objects, often discovered in wide-field surveys and having low surface brightness, require dark skies and specific filters like the Lumicon Oxygen-III for successful observation. The authors provide a table of 10 such nebulae with detailed coordinates and observational data, along with techniques for locating them using reference stars.

articles.title: OBSCURE LARGE WINTER PLANETARY NEBULAE
articles.summary: This article provides a detailed guide to observing several obscure and challenging large planetary nebulae visible in the winter sky. It includes a table with coordinates, sizes, and magnitudes for each object, followed by extensive observational notes from various astronomers using large aperture telescopes (13" to 17.5"). The descriptions emphasize the difficulty of visual detection, effective use of UHC and OIII filters, and specific observing techniques such as averted vision for these faint deep-sky objects.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article discusses the extreme observing challenge presented by deep-sky objects A1E and K2-3, noting failed attempts even with large telescopes. It then provides a review of comet discoveries and recoveries in 1985, highlighting an increase in recoveries and a decrease in amateur discoveries. Finally, it offers detailed ephemerides and observational notes for comets Shoemaker 3 (1985s), Hartley-Good (1985L), and Boethin (1985n) for early 1986.

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND -- HALLEY'S COMET
articles.summary: Five spacecraft are scheduled to visit Halley's Comet this month, conducting close-range examinations using photography, spectrographic, and radio equipment. VEGA 1 (USSR) will pass within 6,000 miles to photograph and take spectrographs, while SUISEI (Japan) will study the comet's hydrogen cloud from 90,000 miles away. These missions aim to gather crucial scientific data and spectacular images of the "dirty snowball."

articles.title: VEGA 2 (USSR) Mar. 9:
articles.summary: The Soviet Vega 2 probe, nearly identical to Vega 1 but launched six days later, is en route to Venus before its encounter with Halley's Comet. It is expected to pass about 6,000 miles from the comet's nucleus, with its final trajectory to be refined after Vega 1's mission. This mission follows a similar path to its predecessor.

articles.title: SAKIGAKE (JAPAN) Mar. 11:
articles.summary: The SAKIGAKE probe, launched on January 7, 1985, is identical to the Suisei probe. Its mission involves passing several million miles from Halley's Comet to study the solar wind from that distance.

articles.title: GIOTTO (EUROPEAN SPACE AGENCY) Mar. 13:
articles.summary: The European Space Agency's Giotto probe will make the closest approach to Halley's Comet nucleus at 300 miles, taking photos and measurements. Concurrently, US probes (Pioneer 12, ICE, Solar Max) will study the comet from varying distances. Earthbound observers in March can track the comet from Capricornus to Sagittarius/Scorpius, with specific dates for moon conjunctions and opportunities to observe it without moonlight, noting its better visibility from lower latitudes.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Halley (1982i) from late February to early April, detailing its celestial coordinates (Right Ascension, Declination), elongation, magnitude, and rise times relative to astronomical twilight at different solar depression angles. This data is essential for observers tracking the comet's position and visibility during this period.

articles.title: HOW MANY ANSWERS DO YOU KNOW?
articles.summary: This document provides the correct answers to a quiz focused on Comet Halley. It addresses historical concerns about cyanogen gas in its tail during its 1910 passage, clarifies that comets are visible for more than a few seconds, details its closest approach date and distance during the 1985-86 visit, and notes the longest recorded interval between its appearances.

articles.title: Comet Facts and Information
articles.summary: This article provides a Q&A-style overview of comets, detailing their composition, tail structure, orbital characteristics like aphelion, and lifespan. A significant portion focuses on Halley's Comet, covering its history, Edmond Halley's contributions, historical appearances (including its link to the Norman Conquest), and space missions that encountered it. The document also touches upon the Oort Cloud and comet formation.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document is a classifieds section featuring advertisements for used astronomical equipment. Items listed for sale include a 4-inch Unitron refractor, a Celestron Super C8 telescope, and a steel building with rotary dome rings suitable for an observatory. The listings provide descriptions, prices, and contact information for potential buyers.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) hosts monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California. These gatherings, held on the 4th Saturday of each month at 8 PM, provide a friendly environment for members to discuss and share various astronomical interests, including astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making.

articles.title: C.T. ENGLISH SCHOOL
articles.summary: The C.T. English School in the Santa Cruz mountains is introduced as a new observing site for the SJAA. The article provides detailed driving directions from Hwy 17, along with instructions for parking and equipment setup, including options to set up near vehicles or in an open field for less light pollution.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Henry Coe State Park, specifically guiding visitors to an observing site used by the SJAA. It includes driving instructions from Hwy 101, information about a locked gate with a club combination (4585), and important advice for arrivals, particularly after dark, regarding parking and site selection.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is identified as a popular astronomical observing site, standing at 3000 ft above sea level, where the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) often sets up at Coulter Camp. The article provides detailed driving directions to the park, noting that 30 to 40 telescopes are common during clear new moon weekends. It also includes the masthead for the SJAA's monthly publication, EPHEMERIS, listing its officers and board of directors.

articles.title: EDITORIAL COMMENT
articles.summary: The article discusses the immediate halt of the U.S. space program following the Challenger disaster and the tragic loss of its 7 astronauts. The author anticipates a significant, non-expeditious delay in resuming flights, leading to a severe backlog of scientific and military missions given the reduced orbiter fleet. The editorial advocates for the construction of a replacement orbiter, and possibly an additional backup, to meet future launch demands, while a secondary comment expresses doubt about funding for new space technologies.

articles.title: UOYAGER RETURNS DETAILED IMAGES OF URANUS SYSTEM
articles.summary: Voyager 2 successfully completed its closest approach to Uranus on January 24th, sending back detailed images of its largest moons. The mission also yielded significant discoveries, including an unexpectedly large magnetic field and several previously unknown small moons orbiting the planet.

articles.title: ERECTABLE TRUSS CHOSEN FOR THE SPACE STATION
articles.summary: An erectable five-meter square truss structure has been selected for the space station's construction, favored over a deployable design. This decision was primarily driven by its simpler design, lower cost, improved remote manipulator system clearance, enhanced structural stiffness, and better accessibility.
